cards.front: What are the five characteristics of a perfectly competitive market?
cards.back:
1) Many buyers and sellers
2) Identical (homogeneous) products
3) Perfect information
4) Free entry and exit
5) Price takers

cards.front: What does 'price taker' mean in perfect competition?
cards.back: Individual firms cannot influence market price. They must accept the market-determined price and can sell any quantity at that price.

cards.front: Why are perfectly competitive firms price takers?
cards.back: Each firm is so small relative to the market that its output decisions don't affect market price. Products are identical, so no buyer would pay more.

cards.front: What is the demand curve faced by an individual perfectly competitive firm?
cards.back: Perfectly elastic (horizontal) at the market price. MR = P = D for the firm.

cards.front: What is the relationship between market demand and firm demand in perfect competition?
cards.back: Market demand slopes downward. Individual firm demand is horizontal at market price. Firm demand ≠ market demand.

cards.front: What is marginal revenue for a perfectly competitive firm?
cards.back: MR = P. Each additional unit sold adds exactly the price to total revenue.

cards.front: What is the profit-maximizing rule for a perfectly competitive firm?
cards.back: Produce where MR = MC. Since MR = P for perfect competition, produce where P = MC.

cards.front: How does a perfectly competitive firm determine its profit-maximizing output?
cards.back: Finds where P = MC on the rising portion of the MC curve.

cards.front: What is the short-run supply curve for a perfectly competitive firm?
cards.back: The portion of the MC curve above the minimum AVC. Shows how much the firm will produce at each price.

cards.front: What is the short-run market supply curve in perfect competition?
cards.back: The horizontal sum of all individual firms' supply curves (MC above AVC).

cards.front: What is the shut-down rule in the short run?
cards.back: Shut down if P < AVC. Continue operating if P > AVC, even if P < ATC (covering variable costs helps minimize losses).

cards.front: Why would a firm continue operating at a loss in the short run?
cards.back: If P > AVC, the firm covers variable costs and contributes something to fixed costs, which must be paid anyway.

cards.front: What is the break-even point for a perfectly competitive firm?
cards.back: Where P = minimum ATC. Firm makes zero economic profit (normal profit only).

cards.front: What happens to economic profits in perfect competition in the long run?
cards.back: They are eliminated by entry of new firms if positive, or exit of firms if negative. Long-run equilibrium: zero economic profit.

cards.front: What is long-run equilibrium in perfect competition?
cards.back: P = MC = minimum ATC. Zero economic profit, only normal profit.

cards.front: What is productive efficiency in perfect competition?
cards.back: Producing at minimum ATC. Achieved in long-run equilibrium.

cards.front: What is allocative efficiency in perfect competition?
cards.back: P = MC. Resources allocated to produce what consumers value most. Achieved in long-run equilibrium.

cards.front: How does entry affect market equilibrium in perfect competition?
cards.back: Entry increases market supply, lowers market price, reduces profits for all firms until zero economic profit.

cards.front: How does exit affect market equilibrium in perfect competition?
cards.back: Exit decreases market supply, raises market price, increases profits for remaining firms until zero economic profit.

cards.front: What is a constant-cost industry in perfect competition?
cards.back: Entry/exit doesn't affect input prices. Long-run supply curve is horizontal at minimum ATC.

cards.front: What is an increasing-cost industry in perfect competition?
cards.back: Entry increases input prices. Long-run supply curve slopes upward.

cards.front: What is a decreasing-cost industry in perfect competition?
cards.back: Entry decreases input prices (rare). Long-run supply curve slopes downward.

cards.front: What is the relationship between short-run and long-run supply?
cards.back: Long-run supply is more elastic because firms can enter/exit and adjust all inputs.

cards.front: What happens when demand increases in a perfectly competitive market?
cards.back:
Short run: Price rises, firms increase output along MC curve, make economic profits.
Long run: Entry occurs, supply increases, price returns to minimum ATC, zero economic profit.

cards.front: What happens when demand decreases in a perfectly competitive market?
cards.back:
Short run: Price falls, firms reduce output along MC curve, incur losses.
Long run: Exit occurs, supply decreases, price returns to minimum ATC, zero economic profit.

cards.front: What is normal profit?
cards.back: The minimum return needed to keep resources in their current use. Included in costs, so zero economic profit includes normal profit.

cards.front: What is the difference between economic profit and accounting profit?
cards.back: Economic profit = Total revenue - All costs (explicit + implicit). Accounting profit = Total revenue - Explicit costs only.

cards.front: Why is perfect competition considered the most efficient market structure?
cards.back: Achieves both productive efficiency (minimum ATC) and allocative efficiency (P = MC) in long run.

cards.front: What is consumer surplus in perfect competition?
cards.back: Area below demand curve and above price. Maximized due to low prices and high output.

cards.front: What is producer surplus in perfect competition?
cards.back: Area above supply curve and below price. Only covers opportunity costs in long run.

cards.front: What is total surplus in perfect competition?
cards.back: Consumer surplus + producer surplus. Maximized, with no deadweight loss.

cards.front: What is the role of profits in perfect competition?
cards.back: Short-run profits signal entry, losses signal exit. Long-run zero economic profit provides normal return to resources.

cards.front: Why do perfectly competitive firms have no incentive to advertise?
cards.back: Products are identical, so advertising wouldn't increase demand for individual firms. Would only increase costs.

cards.front: What is the difference between firm and industry in perfect competition?
cards.back: Firm: Individual producer. Industry: All firms producing the product. Firm decisions don't affect industry, but industry affects firms.

cards.front: What is the shape of the total revenue curve for a perfectly competitive firm?
cards.back: Straight line through origin with slope = P (since TR = P × Q).

cards.front: What is the relationship between price, marginal revenue, and average revenue in perfect competition?
cards.back: P = MR = AR. All are equal and constant for the firm.

cards.front: How does a perfectly competitive firm respond to price changes?
cards.back: Moves along its MC curve. Higher price → produce more. Lower price → produce less (if above AVC).

cards.front: What is the significance of the minimum AVC point?
cards.back: Shut-down point. If price falls below minimum AVC, firm should shut down.

cards.front: What is the significance of the minimum ATC point?
cards.back: Break-even point. In long run, firms produce here with zero economic profit.

cards.front: Why can't perfectly competitive firms earn long-run economic profits?
cards.back: Free entry means new firms enter when profits exist, increasing supply and lowering price until profits disappear.

cards.front: What happens to efficiency when a perfectly competitive market is in long-run equilibrium?
cards.back: Both productive efficiency (minimum ATC) and allocative efficiency (P = MC) are achieved.

cards.front: What is an example of a market that approximates perfect competition?
cards.back: Agricultural markets (wheat, corn), foreign exchange markets, stock markets (for individual stocks).

cards.front: What are the limitations of the perfect competition model?
cards.back: Assumes perfect information, no externalities, homogeneous products, no barriers to entry—conditions rarely met in reality.
